proofed.
The text is taken from an unsigned letterpress copy; however, M to C. Topp, 8 June 1894, is evidently M's reply to this letter. 6th June [189]4
editorial addition.

I have the honor to inform you that His Excellency the Governor in Council has been pleased to retain your services as Government Botanist until the 31st December 1894.
See also M to C. Topp, 8 June 1894.
On 29 May 1894 the Chief Secretary, J. Patterson, recommended to the Governor in Council the continued employment of M, Robert Ellery, Government Astronomer and Henry Hayter, Government Statist. Approval was granted the same day. A certificate continuing the employment of these three until 31 December 1894 was signed by the members of the Public Service Board and dated 28 May and sent to the Premier (Y94/3972, unit 818, VPRS 3992/P, PROV).
It seems another letter was written on 30 August because there is a letter to the Commissioners of Audit dated 3/9 giving the same information, saying that an Order in Council was granted 29 May. This seems to be going in circles — do we need to note this further correspondence.
M's employment continued to be extended by several months at a time. On 14 February 1895 the Under Secretary, C. Topp, minuted:
I beg to recommend that the necessary steps be taken to retain the services of Baron Von Mueller K.C.M.G. &c Government Botanist until the end of this year. I make the recommendation being of opinion that as long as this officer is capable of performing his duties he should continue to hold the position of Government Botanist & that he should therefore be from time to time directed to continue in the service as provided in the Public Service Act.
There is no other officer in the service [in]deed no person in the Colonies possessing such an extensive knowledge of Systematic & Economic Botany as Baron Von Mueller and it is highly desirable that, so long as he is capable, Victoria should have the benefit of his knowledge & enthusiasm and that he should have the facilities which he can possess only as Government Botanist for completing & revising his various publications on the Australian Flora and on general Economic Botany. I may add that as Baron von Mueller devotes the difference between his salary & the pension to which he is entitled to the expenses of keeping up the Botanical Museum &c there would be practically no saving by his retirement.
Cabinet approval of Topp's recommendation was minuted on 19 February 1895 (B95/1520, unit 818, VPRS 3992/P, PROV).
